Award.AwardTitle: RIG: Mechanisms of Molecular Recognition by the Transcription Factor LMO7 at the Nuclear Envelope and the Adherens Junctions

Division.LongName: Div Of Molecular and Cellular Bioscience

Award.AbstractNarration:
LMO7 is a transcription factor that has two distinct roles. At the nucleus it regulates the transcription of genes important for heart, muscle and retina formation. It also plays an adaptor role in stabilizing communication between proteins (cadherin and nectin) that are involved in cell-to-cell junctions. This project will determine at the molecular level 1) the structure-function relationships associated with the recognition processes of two conserved structural domains (PDZ and LIM) within LMO7, and 2) how variations in these domains influence the two functions (adaptor and transcriptional regulator) of the LMO7 protein. Nuclear Magnetic Resonance (NMR) spectroscopy, molecular biological, biochemical and biophysical methods will be employed to understand specific interactions and the dynamic structural changes that occur upon binding. Results from the atomic level high-resolution structures will provide information for the design of mutagenesis experiments that will advance our understanding of the protein-protein assembly process. These studies will define the differences and similarities between the interactions that are relevant to multi-molecular assembly within the cadherin-nectin containing complexes, as compared to those interactions required for the regulation of gene transcription in the nucleus.

Broader Impacts
This project will provide graduate, undergraduate and high school students the opportunity to participate in structural biology research on the structure of proteins, the regulation of gene expression, and specific mechanisms of molecular recognition. A special emphasis will be placed on the recruitment to this project of students from economically disadvantaged backgrounds as well as members of minorities under-represented in scientific research. High school students will be mentored through a Project SEED program of the American Chemical Society. Aspects of this project will be integrated into courses at both graduate and undergraduate levels, and students involved in this research will have the opportunity to present their results at regional and national conferences.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The LIM domain only-7 protein, LMO7, is an adaptor protein with two distinct functional roles in the cell. LMO7 is involved in stabilizing communication between proteins associated with cadherin and nectin that are part of the cell-to-cell junctions. Within the nucleus, LMO7 regulates the transcription of genes important for heart, muscle and retina formation. These studies focused on interactions mediated by domains of LMO7 relevant to the assembly of cadherin-associated and nectin-associated complexes. Nuclear Magnetic Resonance (NMR) spectroscopy, molecular biological, biochemical and biophysical methods were employed to characterize specific interactions and the dynamic structural changes that occur as a result of protein-protein associations. The results from this project provide insight into the conformational changes that are directly associated with the regulation of function through these domains in LMO7 and by defining at the molecular level structure-function relationships associated with the recognition processes of structured and unstructured regions in LMO7. The knowledge acquired from these structural studies advances our understanding of the mechanisms of self-assembly and protein-protein assembly by conserved structural domains commonly found in adaptor proteins.

This project has provided high school, undergraduate and graduate students the opportunity to participate in structural biology research, which explores the mechanisms involved in molecular recognition connected to the regulation of gene expression. The high school students participating as a result of this award were mentored through two summer programs for local high school students. One of these programs was a Project SEED program of the American Chemical Society, which puts a special emphasis on providing students from economically disadvantaged backgrounds and members of under-represented groups in science an opportunity to engage in scientific research. The undergraduate students that participated in the research in this award were part of the NSF-REU program and other institutional programs encouraging participation in research at the undergraduate level. The students involved in this research had the opportunity to present their results at local, regional and national conferences. Aspects of this project were successfully integrated into courses at both the graduate and undergraduate levels.
